channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: South Korean Novelist Apologizes in Wake of Plagiarism Accusation
item.description: Shin Kyung-sook, whose novel “Please Look After Mom” won the Man Asian Literary Prize in 2011, said she may have plagiarized material for a short story decades ago.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Republican Case for Obama’s Cuba Policy
item.description: Cuban-Americans and the G.O.P. must look to the future instead of the past. Ordinary Cubans need trade and engagement, not more isolation.
item.dc:creator: CARLOS M. GUTIERREZ

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Iran Deal’s Fatal Flaw
item.description: It won’t actually buy us more time if Tehran decides to build a bomb.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: ALAN J. KUPERMAN

item.title: U.S. and China Set to Meet, With Few Expectations
item.description: The fact that top officials of the two nations are talking, at a two-day meeting in Washington, is seen as positive at a time when they seem far apart.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES

item.title: Samsung Heir Apparent Apologizes for Hospital’s Role in MERS Outbreak
item.description: Lee Jae-yong, who is being groomed to run the South Korean conglomerate, made a televised apology for a Samsung hospital’s failures in dealing with the outbreak.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. and China Set to Meet, With Few Expectations
item.description: The fact that top officials of the two nations are talking, at a two-day meeting in Washington, is seen as positive at a time when they seem far apart.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES

item.title: Four Prominent Chilean Politicians Are Charged With Tax Fraud
item.description: These are the first politicians to appear before a court as prosecutors unravel a high-profile corruption case related to illegal campaign financing.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: World Briefing: Panel Is Named to Investigate Handling of Allegations Against French Troops
item.description: An independent panel will examine how the United Nations handled an inquiry into accusations that French peacekeepers sexually abused children in the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Risk of Extreme Weather From Climate Change to Rise Over Next Century, Report Says
item.description: More people will be exposed to floods, droughts, heat waves and other effects of climate change in the coming decades, according to a British medical journal.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Drought in Puerto Rico has left the La Plata reservoir nearly empty. A study in The Lancet predicts a growing number of people will be affected by extreme weather over the next century.

item.title: One Dead as Druse Attack Israeli Ambulance in Golan Heights
item.description: It was the second time in 24 hours that Druse protesters stopped Israeli ambulances, amid mounting anger in their communities over the rebel assaults on Druse villages on the Syrian side.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: As South Sudan Crisis Worsens, ‘There Is No More Country’
item.description: In the world’s newest nation, the fighting, atrocities and hunger have increased, with no end in sight to the warring leaders’ power struggle.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: The population of Wau Shilluk, a swampland village on the Nile, has swelled as people have fled their homes seeking safety from marauding soldiers.

item.title: U.S. Says Drone Killed an ISIS Operative
item.description: The Pentagon said that a “person of interest” in the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, died in coordinated airstrikes in Mosul, Iraq, on June 15.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Tariq bin al-Tahar bin al-Falih al-Awni al-Harzi
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Optimism for an Agreement on Greek Debt, but Not for Long-Term Stability
item.description: Fears remain that any easing of the Greek crisis when all 28 European Union leaders meet on Thursday and Friday will be short-term.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Greeks read news reports in Athens on Monday, when Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras arrived in Brussels for a eurozone meeting.

item.title: Government in Ethiopia Is on Track to Win With 100% of Vote
item.description: Ethiopia’s governing party and its allies are poised to control every seat in the nation’s Parliament, according to official results announced Monday.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Reversing Course, Pakistan Says Save the Children Can Stay
item.description: Pressure from Western allies will allow the aid agency to continue its operations, though on a smaller scale and with tighter restrictions.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Unicef Report Describes Grim Trends for the Poorest Children
item.description: The United Nations Children’s Fund said improvements in national averages had obscured worsening trends among the world’s poorest children.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.N. Report on Gaza Finds Evidence of War Crimes by Israel and by Palestinian Militants
item.description: The report said “impunity prevails across the board” regarding the actions of Israeli forces in Gaza, but also cited the “inherently indiscriminate nature” of rockets fired at Israeli civilians.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians mourned members of the Nigim family who were killed during an Israeli airstrike in Jabaliya, Gaza, on August 4, 2014.

item.title: Itineraries: AirAsia Faces Red Tape and Tough Competition in India
item.description: AirAsia has exported its low-cost model to India, hoping to catch its hundreds of millions in first-time fliers. It has proven harder than expected.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: MAX BEARAK
item.media:credit: Sami Siva for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mittu Chandilya, chief executive of AirAsia India, beside one of its aircraft in Delhi. The low-cost airline aims to capture a growing market in India.

item.title: Iraqi Families Return to Fragile Stability in Tikrit After Liberation From ISIS
item.description: The Islamic State was driven from Tikrit, the hometown of Saddam Hussein and the largest city the terrorist group has lost in either Iraq or Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and TIM ARANGO

item.title: Human Rights Watch Accuses World Bank of Inaction When Protesters Face Reprisals
item.description: A Human Rights Watch report pointed to cases in which those who protested bank-supported projects were harassed and intimidated by governments.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Brick kilns outside New Delhi, India. A hydroelectric project in northern India financed by the World Bank was met with protests.
